content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student is interested in studying the <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> ion, which is important in the environment. <math alttext="C u, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2, aqueous, plus K 3 P O 4, aqueous, reacts to produce" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cu</mi><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><msub><mi>NO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi>PO</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>→</mo></math> (a) First, the student carries out a precipitation reaction. A solution of copper(II) nitrate is mixed with a solution of potassium phosphate, as represented above, and a blue precipitate forms. Write the balanced net ionic equation for the process.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A student is interested in studying the <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> ion, which is important in the environment. <math alttext="C u, open parenthesis, N O 3, close parenthesis, 2, aqueous, plus K 3 P O 4, aqueous, reacts to produce" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cu</mi><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><msub><mi>NO</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>+</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><msub><mi>PO</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mo>→</mo></math> (a) First, the student carries out a precipitation reaction. A solution of copper(II) nitrate is mixed with a solution of potassium phosphate, as represented above, and a blue precipitate forms. Write the balanced net ionic equation for the process.

(b) In a separate experiment the student decides to precipitate the <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> as <math alttext="C u, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cu</mi><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>OH</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. To make sure that <math alttext="C u, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cu</mi><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>OH</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> will precipitate, the student looks up the <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> value for <math alttext="C u, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cu</mi><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>OH</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>, as shown below.<math alttext="C u, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid is in equilibrium with C u with a positive 2 charge, aqueous, plus 2 O H with a negative 1 charge, aqueous. K s p equals, 2.2 times 10 raised to the negative 20 power." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cu</mi><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>OH</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mtable><mtr><mtd><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mo> </mo><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mo>⇄</mo><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mo> </mo><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msup><mi>OH</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mtd><mtd><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2.2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></msup></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>(i) Write the <math alttext="K s p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></math> expression for the dissolving of <math alttext="C u, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2, solid" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cu</mi><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>OH</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>.

(ii) Calculate the concentration of <math alttext="C u with a positive 2 charge, aqueous" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>Cu</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> in a saturated <math alttext="C u, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Cu</mi><msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>OH</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded><mn>2</mn></msub></math> solution in <math alttext="moles per liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>mol</mi><mo>/</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></math>.

(c) The student incorrectly proposes that lowering the <math alttext="p H" overflow="scroll"><mi>pH</mi></math> of the saturated <math alttext="C u, open parenthesis, O H, close parenthesis, 2" overflow="scroll"> <mi>Cu</mi> <msub> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>OH</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </math> solution will increase the amount of precipitate that forms. Explain why the student is incorrect.

skill.text: 5.B: Identify an appropriate theory, definition, or mathematical relationship to solve a problem.
